sections.title: Introduction to Synthetic Biology and Genetic Engineering
sections.tldr: Synthetic biology represents a merger of engineering principles with biological systems to create novel functionalities through the manipulation of genetic components. The field builds upon decades of advances in genetic engineering techniques while incorporating computational approaches and standardized biological parts to develop predictable and robust biological systems. (11 sources)
sections.text:
Synthetic biology has emerged as a dynamic interdisciplinary field that applies engineering principles to biological systems, enabling the creation of novel functionalities not found in nature <Paper corpusId="14223948" paperTitle="(Reeve et al., 2013)" isShortName></Paper> <Paper corpusId="3491582" paperTitle="(Gumulya et al., 2018)" isShortName></Paper> <Paper corpusId="7001838" paperTitle="(Serrano, 2007)" isShortName></Paper>. This field distinguishes itself through its approach of treating biological components as modular parts that can be characterized, standardized, and assembled to build complex systems <Paper corpusId="19324379" paperTitle="(Li et al., 2016)" isShortName></Paper> <Paper corpusId="58547759" paperTitle="(Abram et al., 2018)" isShortName></Paper>.

While synthetic biology became formally recognized in the early 2000s, its foundations rest on decades of developments in genetic engineering dating back to the 1970s <Paper corpusId="265507478" paperTitle="(Pfeifer et al., 2023)" isShortName></Paper> <Paper corpusId="2555043" paperTitle="(Cohen et al., 1973)" isShortName></Paper>. The breakthrough discovery of restriction enzymes and recombinant DNA technology by Cohen and colleagues provided the fundamental tools to manipulate genetic material in unprecedented ways, setting the stage for more complex engineering of biological systems <Paper corpusId="265507478" paperTitle="(Pfeifer et al., 2023)" isShortName></Paper> <Paper corpusId="2555043" paperTitle="(Cohen et al., 1973)" isShortName></Paper>.

The field has been propelled forward by significant technological advances including de novo DNA synthesis, protein engineering, and the development of artificial gene networks <Paper corpusId="14223948" paperTitle="(Reeve et al., 2013)" isShortName></Paper> <Paper corpusId="15342086" paperTitle="(Heinemann et al., 2006)" isShortName></Paper>. These advances have enabled researchers to design and construct biological systems with predetermined behaviors, applying circuit-like analogies from electrical engineering to biological regulation <Paper corpusId="55369011" paperTitle="(Wang et al., 2011)" isShortName></Paper> <Paper corpusId="5422808" paperTitle="(Chen et al., 2010)" isShortName></Paper>.

A key principle of synthetic biology is the abstraction of complex biological processes into modular components or "biological parts" that can be assembled in various combinations to create new functionalities <Paper corpusId="58547759" paperTitle="(Abram et al., 2018)" isShortName></Paper>. This engineering-driven approach emphasizes purpose-orientation, standardization, and separation of design and fabrication processes <Paper corpusId="15342086" paperTitle="(Heinemann et al., 2006)" isShortName></Paper>.

Recent years have seen dramatic growth in synthetic biology applications, facilitated by decreasing costs of DNA sequencing and synthesis <Paper corpusId="91598254" paperTitle="(Shevelev et al., 2018)" isShortName></Paper>. This economic shift has enabled researchers to create and test numerous genetic constructs without the time-consuming traditional methods of molecular biology. Notable successes include microbial production of artemisinin for malaria treatment and the development of automated systems for constructing DNA-based logic circuits <Paper corpusId="3491582" paperTitle="(Gumulya et al., 2018)" isShortName></Paper>.

The integration of computational modeling with biological engineering has further accelerated the field, allowing for predictive design of biological systems <Paper corpusId="5422808" paperTitle="(Chen et al., 2010)" isShortName></Paper>. This convergence of biology, engineering, and computational approaches continues to expand the possibilities for creating robust biological systems with novel applications across medicine, agriculture, and industrial biotechnology <Paper corpusId="14223948" paperTitle="(Reeve et al., 2013)" isShortName></Paper> <Paper corpusId="15342086" paperTitle="(Heinemann et al., 2006)" isShortName></Paper>.

paper.title: Predicting Translation Initiation Rates for Designing Synthetic Biology

snippets: Synthetic biology is a recently emerged field concerned with engineering complex living systems by assembling individually characterized biological parts in novel combinations. The discipline arose from the discovery of the mathematical logic of gene pairings, as well as from advances made in genetic engineering and recombinant DNA technology (Andrianantoandro et al., 2006). The development of de novo DNA synthesis, protein engineering, and the designs of artificial gene networks have greatly contributed to the field's advancement (Heinemann et al., 2006).

paper.title: In a Quest for Engineering Acidophiles for Biomining Applications: Challenges and Opportunities

snippets: As an emerging research field of bioengineering, synthetic biology has undergone dramatic growth throughout the past decade. Synthetic biology, which can be described as the engineering of biology: the synthesis of complex, biologically based systems, which display functions that do not exist in nature (Serrano, 2007), has transformed how scientists can apply biology for the benefit of society. Well-characterised biological parts that are integrated into a well-known host (i.e. chassis) have resulted in many synthetic biology success stories, such as microbial artemisinin production for malaria treatment (Paddon et al., 2013) and automated systems for the construction of DNA-based logic circuits (Nielsen et al., 2016).

paper.title: Synthetic biology: promises and challenges

snippets:
Mol Syst Biol. 3: 158

Life is evolving fast (at least in the first world) and the latest technological gadget becomes outdated even before we have learnt how to use it. In this respect, science is no exception. The new buzzword ‘Systems Biology’ entered the vocabulary of the scientific community only a few years ago. Now that every biologist is aware of it and almost everyone seems to be doing it, an even newer buzzword has entered the scientific arena, ‘Synthetic Biology’ (see as an example a sample of recent reviews on the topic, Benner and Sismour, 2005; Endy, 2005; Andrianantoandro et al , 2006; Heinemann and Panke, 2006).

We are still arguing about the true definition of Systems Biology, the more so since it became fashionable for the funding agencies and therefore any research project should include it in the proposal, and now we need to define Synthetic Biology and explain to the non‐specialist what the difference is between the two. Is Synthetic Biology something really new or is it simply Biotechnology (another old and outdated buzzword) in new packaging? What are the achievements so far, what can we expect from it and are any biosafety dangers lurking ahead? How is Europe doing in this field compared with other countries? In this brief article we will attempt to provide some answers to those questions.

A consensus definition drafted by a group of European experts defined Synthetic Biology as follows: ‘Synthetic biology is the engineering of biology: the synthesis of complex, biologically based (or inspired) systems, which display functions that do not exist in nature. This engineering perspective may be applied at all levels of the hierarchy of biological structures—from individual molecules to whole cells, tissues and organisms. In essence, synthetic biology will enable the …

paper.title: Synbiological systems for complex natural products biosynthesis

snippets: Synthetic biology is an emerging filed with the development with DNA sequencing technology, DNA recombinant technology, computational biology, and biological engineering. It distinguishes itself from other disciplines in both its approach and its choice of object. Synthetic biology should be considered a hybrid discipline, combining both engineering and science to achieve its goal of engineering synthetic organisms.

paper.title: Towards a better metabolic engineering reference: the microbial chassis

snippets:
Synthetic biology consists of the manipulation and rationalization of complex biological processes to design or re-purpose biological systems for useful applications (Purnick et al., 2009). As with any engineering device, a certain level of abstraction is necessary to obtain a functional representation of a complex problem. For synthetic biology, the various biological components of the complex problem being investigated are represented in terms of biological parts or devices. These biological parts or devices could be 'plugged-in' to a microbial chassis to address a given need. Once 'plugged-in' to the chassis, these parts begin interacting under the corresponding genetic programme which encodes the target function. 

With the assistance of genetic engineering, synthetic biology has rapidly advanced over the last few years for certain well-characterized organisms such as Escherichia coli or Bacillus subtilis.

paper.title: Harnessing synthetic biology for advancing RNA therapeutics and vaccine design

snippets: Synthetic biology is a scientific field that involves the rewiring of organisms or biomolecular parts for new and desired abilities. This encompasses diverse applications, from engineering new or improved activities in enzymes, heterologous production of commodity chemicals, assembly of genetic parts in a synthetic manner and developing cellular therapies. Although synthetic biology itself is a relatively new field that emerged in the early 2000's, the tools required to engineer living systems were under development for decades before the field of synthetic biology was officially founded and its roots can be traced all the way back to the discovery and development of genetic engineering techniques in the 1970s (Cohen et al., 1973) . These scientific breakthroughs allowed scientists to manipulate DNA in unprecedented ways and opened the door for a wave of innovation in genetic engineering, such as the invention of polymerase chain reaction in 1983 4 , which allowed researchers to amplify DNA sequences for use in genetic manipulation.

paper.title: Construction of biologically functional bacterial plasmids in vitro.
paper.venue: Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences of the United States of America

snippets: The construction of new plasmid DNA species by in vitro joining of restriction endonuclease-generated fragments of separate plasmids is described. Newly constructed plasmids that are inserted into Escherichia coli by transformation are shown to be biologically functional replicons that possess genetic properties and nucleotide base sequences from both of the parent DNA molecules. Functional plasmids can be obtained by reassociation of endonuclease-generated fragments of larger replicons, as well as by joining of plasmid DNA molecules of entirely different origins.

paper.title: Synthetic biology - putting engineering into biology

snippets: Synthetic biology is interpreted as the engineering-driven building of increasingly complex biological entities for novel applications. Encouraged by progress in the design of artificial gene networks, de novo DNA synthesis and protein engineering, we review the case for this emerging discipline. Key aspects of an engineering approach are purpose-orientation, deep insight into the underlying scientific principles, a hierarchy of abstraction including suitable interfaces between and within the levels of the hierarchy, standardization and the separation of design and fabrication. Synthetic biology investigates possibilities to implement these requirements into the process of engineering biological systems. This is illustrated on the DNA level by the implementation of engineering-inspired artificial operations such as toggle switching, oscillating or production of spatial patterns. On the protein level, the functionally self-contained domain structure of a number of proteins suggests possibilities for essentially Lego-like recombination which can be exploited for reprogramming DNA binding domain specificities or signaling pathways. Alternatively, computational design emerges to rationally reprogram enzyme function. Finally, the increasing facility of de novo DNA synthesis-synthetic biology's system fabrication process-supplies the possibility to implement novel designs for ever more complex systems. Some of these elements have merged to realize the first tangible synthetic biology applications in the area of manufacturing of pharmaceutical compounds.

paper.title: Promising Role of Engineered Gene Circuits in Gene Therapy

snippets: Synthetic biology is concerned with applying the engineering paradigm of systems design to biological systems in order to produce predictable and robust systems with novel functionalities that do not exist in nature. The circuit-like connectivity of biological parts and their ability to collectively process logical operations was first appreciated nearly 50 years ago. This inspired attempts to describe biological regulation schemes with mathematical models and to apply circuit analogies from established frameworks in electrical engineering(McAdams & Arkin A,2000). Meanwhile, breakthroughs in genomic research and genetic engineering (e.g., recombinant DNA technology) were supplying the inventory and methods necessary to physically construct and assemble biomolecular parts.

paper.title: Stochastic Game Theory Approach to Robust Synthetic Gene Network Design

snippets: Synthetic biology builds living machines from the off-the-shelf chemical ingredients, utilizing many of the same strategies that electrical engineers employ to make computer chips (Tucker & Zilinskas, 2006). The main goal of the nascent field of synthetic biology is to design and construct biological systems with the desired behavior (Alon, 2003; Alon, 2007; Andrianantoandro et al., 2006; Church, 2005; Endy, 2005; Hasty et al., 2002; Heinemann & Panke, 2006; Kobayashi et al., 2004; Pleiss, 2006; Tucker & Zilinskas, 2006). By a set of powerful techniques for the automated synthesis of DNA molecules and their assembly into genes and microbial genomes, synthetic biology envisions the redesign of natural biological systems for greater efficiency as well as the construction of functional "genetic circuit" and metabolic pathways for practical purposes (Andrianantoandro, et al., 2006; Ferber, 2004; Forster & Church, 2007; Gardner, et al., 2000; Heinemann & Panke, 2006; Isaacs, et al., 2006; Maeda & Sano, 2006; Tucker & Parker, 2000).

paper.title: Современные подходы к синтезу генов: аспекты синтеза олигонуклеотидов, ферментативной сборки, проверки последовательностей и коррекции ошибок

snippets: Synthetic biology is a rapidly developing field aimed at engineering of biological systems with predictable properties. Synthetic biology accumulates the achievements of modern biological sciences, programming and computational model­ing as well as engineering technologies for creation of biologi­cal objects with user-defined properties. Evolution of synthetic biology has been marked by a number of technological developments in each of the mentioned fields. Thus, significant reduction in cost of DNA sequencing has provided an easy access to large amounts of data on the genetic sequences of various organisms, and decreased the price of the DNA sequence synthesis, which, analogous to Moore's law, resulted in an opportunity to create a lot of potential genes without the time – consuming and labor – intensive traditional methods of molecular biology.

sections.title: Advances in DNA Synthesis and Assembly Techniques
sections.tldr: Modern DNA synthesis and assembly techniques have revolutionized genetic engineering by enabling efficient construction of custom DNA sequences and complex genetic circuits. These technological advances include high-fidelity assembly methods, standardized vector systems, and commercial DNA synthesis that collectively allow researchers to design and implement sophisticated genetic constructs with unprecedented precision. (11 sources)
sections.text:
The ability to design and construct custom genetic elements represents a fundamental advancement in synthetic biology and protein expression systems. Technological innovations in DNA synthesis and assembly have dramatically enhanced researchers' capacity to create controllable genetic constructs with base-level precision <Paper corpusId="18666432" paperTitle="(Fong, 2014)" isShortName></Paper>. These improvements enable detailed investigation of sequence-to-function relationships and provide finer control over gene expression in metabolic pathways, representing a significant breakthrough for protein production applications <Paper corpusId="18666432" paperTitle="(Fong, 2014)" isShortName></Paper>.

Modern DNA synthesis methods have largely overcome earlier technical limitations that constrained genetic engineering efforts <Paper corpusId="271232593" paperTitle="(Matuszynska et al., 2024)" isShortName></Paper>. These advances have established the foundation for designing increasingly complex systems, including biocellular factories and synthetic protocells <Paper corpusId="271232593" paperTitle="(Matuszynska et al., 2024)" isShortName></Paper> <Paper corpusId="73472159" paperTitle="(Joesaar et al., 2019)" isShortName></Paper>. Commercial DNA synthesis services now offer economical de novo DNA synthesis, significantly increasing the efficiency of traditional recombinant DNA technology <Paper corpusId="6643227" paperTitle="(Young et al., 2010)" isShortName></Paper> <Paper corpusId="43247514" paperTitle="(Tian et al., 2009)" isShortName></Paper>.

Despite these advances, long repetitive DNA fragments still pose synthetic challenges, highlighting the ongoing need for new technologies that enable modular construction of complex synthetic genes <Paper corpusId="245723691" paperTitle="(Skowron et al., 2021)" isShortName></Paper>. Whole-gene synthesis techniques are increasingly utilized to optimize coding sequences for recombinant protein production, particularly when genes contain repetitive sequences that are unstable in bacterial hosts or are non-optimal for expression <Paper corpusId="5627135" paperTitle="(Lu et al., 2009)" isShortName></Paper>.

The synthetic biology toolkit has expanded to include well-characterized expression vectors, promoters for dynamic pathway control, tunable protein degradation systems, and advanced genome editing methods <Paper corpusId="255981073" paperTitle="(Ye et al., 2021)" isShortName></Paper>. Standardized vector collections, such as BglBrick-compatible plasmids, have been developed with various combinations of replication origins, antibiotic resistance genes, and inducible promoters to increase the predictability of gene expression <Paper corpusId="255981073" paperTitle="(Ye et al., 2021)" isShortName></Paper> <Paper corpusId="714878" paperTitle="(Lee et al., 2011)" isShortName></Paper>.

These collective advancements in DNA synthesis and assembly enable researchers to generate custom-made DNA molecules with desired properties, sometimes without even requiring a source DNA sample <Paper corpusId="90517433" paperTitle="(Bernardo, 2017)" isShortName></Paper>. The creation of new biological parts, devices, and modules is now limited primarily by imagination and design capabilities rather than technical constraints <Paper corpusId="90517433" paperTitle="(Bernardo, 2017)" isShortName></Paper>. State-of-the-art DNA synthesis methods developed in industry continue to accelerate the supply of long DNA fragments, further enabling sophisticated genetic engineering and genome editing applications <Paper corpusId="264369680" paperTitle="(Yamagata, 2023)" isShortName></Paper>.

paper.title: Computational approaches to metabolic engineering utilizing systems biology and synthetic biology

snippets: Experimentally, the rapid development of molecular biology and genetic engineering tools typified by synthetic biology has significantly increased the ability to explicitly design and implement controllable genetic constructs. These improvements were enabled by the technological advances in DNA synthesis and rapid, high-fidelity assembly of DNA fragments (Gibson et al., 2009)(Sleight et al., 2013)(Annaluru et al., 2014). Once genetic circuits could be constructed in an efficient and inexpensive manner with base-by-base specificity, it was possible to interrogate sequence-to-function relationships. While central to the investigation of all biological functions, for metabolic engineering applications this represented a broad advance where finer control over the expression of genes in a given pathway could be designed and implemented.

paper.title: A new era of synthetic biology—microbial community design

snippets: The construction of the first synthetic circuits at the 'dawn' of synthetic biology was highly reliant on breaking genetic control systems down into definable parts and then collecting and using existing quantitative data that were most important for the function of these parts when used in different contexts (Gardner et al., 2000)(Elowitz et al., 2000). While earlier engineering was, in part, restrained by technical limitations on what could be cloned, this restriction has largely evaporated in recent years. Improved DNA synthesis and assembly techniques have laid the groundwork for designing increasingly complex systems, such as biocellular and cell-free multipurpose metabolic factories, and the design of synthetic protocells and xenobiological systems (Kong et al., 2018)(Freund et al., 2021)(Joesaar et al., 2019).

paper.title: DNA-based Communication in Populations of Synthetic Protocells

snippets: Developing molecular communication platforms based on orthogonal communication channels is a crucial step towards engineering artificial multicellular systems. Here, we present a general and scalable platform entitled ‘biomolecular implementation of protocellular communication’ (BIO-PC) to engineer distributed multichannel molecular communication between populations of non-lipid semipermeable microcapsules. Our method leverages the modularity and scalability of enzyme-free DNA strand-displacement circuits to develop protocellular consortia that can sense, process and respond to DNA-based messages. We engineer a rich variety of biochemical communication devices capable of cascaded amplification, bidirectional communication and distributed computational operations. Encapsulating DNA strand-displacement circuits further allows their use in concentrated serum where non-compartmentalized DNA circuits cannot operate. BIO-PC enables reliable execution of distributed DNA-based molecular programs in biologically relevant environments and opens new directions in DNA computing and minimal cell technology.Semipermeable proteinosome membranes allow complex DNA message communication through compartmentalization and protect the DNA circuits from degradation in a biological environment.

paper.title: Synthetic Biology: Tools to Design, Build, and Optimize Cellular Processes

snippets: Synthetic biology aims to develop foundational technologies such as large-scale, economical de novo DNA synthesis (Tian et al., 2009) that would increase the efficiency of traditional recombinant DNA technology and genetic engineering. Collectively, synthetic engineering of the central dogma aims to optimize and expand the capabilities of native cellular machinery. The methods and technologies developed from this research will contribute to a more powerful and efficient toolbox for the microbial engineer.

paper.title: Advancing high-throughput gene synthesis technology.

snippets: The emerging field of synthetic biology is generating insatiable demands for synthetic genes, which far exceed existing gene synthesis capabilities. This review discusses the current methods of chemical DNA synthesis and gene assembly, as well as the latest engineering tools, technologies and trends which could potentially lead to breakthroughs in the development of accurate, low-cost and high-throughput gene synthesis technology. The capability of generating unlimited supplies of DNA molecules of any sequence or size will transform biomedical research in the near future.

snippets: DNA sequences of the designed, synthetic genes may require long repetitive DNA fragments. However, the chemical synthesis of such fragments still poses a great challenge. Thus, there is a current need for the development of new technologies, enabling modular construction of complex synthetic genes.

paper.title: Next-Generation Synthetic Gene Networks

snippets: Engineered cells have long been used to produce recombinant proteins and chemicals for the biotechnology industry, and one of the major applications of synthetic biology to date has been in enhancing microbial production of biofuels132 and biomaterials133-136. Improving production from cells involves numerous engineering decisions related to the entire organism, including codon optimization, choosing whether or not to export recombinant proteins137, rational or evolutionary methods for improving metabolic yields138, 139, and optimization of growth conditions. Often some or all of the genes required for production are non-optimal for bacterial expression and contain repetitive sequences that are unstable in bacterial hosts. Whole-gene synthesis techniques are increasingly being used to optimize coding sequences for recombinant production136.

paper.title: CRISPR/Cas9 mediated T7 RNA polymerase gene knock-in in E. coli BW25113 makes T7 expression system work efficiently

snippets: In recent years, biosynthesis techniques have attracted increased attention. As synthetic biology applications have grown in complexity, so too has the sophistication of available genetic and biochemical tools

Thanks to development of genetic engineering, accomplishments have progressed from simple reconstitution of biosynthetic pathways in heterologous hosts to ambitious refactoring efforts (Yamanaka et al., 2014)(Shao et al., 2013)(Temme et al., 2012) that can produce high titers of medicinally relevant compounds (strictosamide, taxa-diene, etc. ) (Brown et al., 2015)(Soliman et al., 2015) or amino acids (L-valine, L-threonine, etc. ) (Park et al., 2007)(Lee et al., 2007). Up to now, synthetic biologists have employed many tools to modify and reform bacterial strains to produce desired compounds. These tools include well-characterized sets of expression vectors (Lee et al., 2011), promoters for dynamic pathway control (Dahl et al., 2013)(Zhang et al., 2012), tunable protein degradation (Cameron et al., 2014), and advanced methods for genome editing (Wang et al., 2009)(Hsu et al., 2014).

paper.title: BglBrick vectors and datasheets: A synthetic biology platform for gene expression

snippets: BackgroundAs engineered biological systems become more complex, it is increasingly common to express multiple operons from different plasmids and inducible expression systems within a single host cell. Optimizing such systems often requires screening combinations of origins of replication, expression systems, and antibiotic markers. This procedure is hampered by a lack of quantitative data on how these components behave when more than one origin of replication or expression system are used simultaneously. Additionally, this process can be time consuming as it often requires the creation of new vectors or cloning into existing but disparate vectors.ResultsHere, we report the development and characterization of a library of expression vectors compatible with the BglBrick standard (BBF RFC 21). We have designed and constructed 96 BglBrick-compatible plasmids with a combination of replication origins, antibiotic resistance genes, and inducible promoters. These plasmids were characterized over a range of inducer concentrations, in the presence of non-cognate inducer molecules, and with several growth media, and their characteristics were documented in a standard format datasheet. A three plasmid system was used to investigate the impact of multiple origins of replication on plasmid copy number.ConclusionsThe standardized collection of vectors presented here allows the user to rapidly construct and test the expression of genes with various combinations of promoter strength, inducible expression system, copy number, and antibiotic resistance. The quantitative datasheets created for these vectors will increase the predictability of gene expression, especially when multiple plasmids and inducers are utilized.

paper.title: Escherichia coli as a Model Organism and Its Application in Biotechnology

snippets: With the avenue of in vitro DNA synthesis to generate larger fragments with increased fidelity along with novel assembly methods, we are now capable of generating large and custommade DNA molecules with the desired properties or even without the source of a DNA sample having only the sequence itself. New biological parts (genes, promoter sequence, terminators, etc.), devices (gene networks), and modules (biosynthetic pathways) are only limited by our imagination and the drive to create them. Also, without the advancement of methods for analyzing large amounts of data, bioinformatics, codon optimization software, genome mining, and user-friendly databases, synthetic biology creations are permeating in many laboratories around the world.

snippets:
Genetic engineering and genome editing: 

These techniques are used to alter the genetic makeup of an organism. This can be achieved by inserting new genes, removing existing genes, rewriting nucleotide sequences, or changing the order of genes. The recent state-of-art DNA synthesis methods developed in industry could accelerate the supply of long DNA. Relevant technologies include directed evolution, viral vectors, embryo manipulation, and cell/organoid culture.

sections.title: Modern Tools and Approaches for Recombinant Protein Expression
sections.tldr: Modern recombinant protein expression has been transformed by synthetic biology approaches that integrate standardized genetic parts, advanced assembly methods, and precise control systems. These tools include CRISPR/Cas9-based genome editing, tunable expression systems, and engineered feedback mechanisms that collectively enable more predictable and efficient protein production across various applications. (15 sources)
sections.text:
Recombinant protein production represents a process of significant industrial importance, with applications ranging from pharmaceuticals to biofuels <Paper corpusId="1609760" paperTitle="(Dragosits et al., 2012)" isShortName></Paper> <Paper corpusId="255984074" paperTitle="(Dragosits et al._1, 2012)" isShortName></Paper>. While traditional approaches to optimize protein expression have often relied on laborious trial-and-error techniques, synthetic biology has introduced systematic, principled methods that dramatically enhance protein production capabilities <Paper corpusId="1609760" paperTitle="(Dragosits et al., 2012)" isShortName></Paper>.

Recent years have witnessed a fundamental shift in functional protein expression paralleling advances in systems and synthetic biology. The integration of high-throughput data on DNA, RNA, proteins, and metabolites has enabled researchers to visualize and understand transcriptional and translational processes at a systems level <Paper corpusId="211050066" paperTitle="(Kim et al., 2020)" isShortName></Paper> <Paper corpusId="15349814" paperTitle="(Nakahigashi et al., 2009)" isShortName></Paper>. This data-driven understanding, combined with robust computational tools and sophisticated DNA assembly techniques, has provided a knowledge-based framework for rational design of biological systems with enhanced protein production capabilities <Paper corpusId="211050066" paperTitle="(Kim et al., 2020)" isShortName></Paper>.

The synthetic biology toolkit for protein expression has expanded considerably to include well-characterized expression vectors, promoters for dynamic pathway control, and tunable protein degradation systems <Paper corpusId="233703833" paperTitle="(Ye et al._1, 2021)" isShortName></Paper>. These components enable precise control over gene expression, with standardized vector collections like BglBrick-compatible plasmids offering various combinations of replication origins, antibiotic resistance genes, and inducible promoters <Paper corpusId="233703833" paperTitle="(Ye et al._1, 2021)" isShortName></Paper> <Paper corpusId="714878" paperTitle="(Lee et al., 2011)" isShortName></Paper>. Such systems allow researchers to rapidly construct and test genes with different promoter strengths, expression systems, and copy numbers.

Genome editing technologies, particularly CRISPR/Cas9, have become instrumental in enhancing protein yields <Paper corpusId="267175973" paperTitle="(Abdulsalam et al., 2024)" isShortName></Paper>. These tools enable precise modification of host organisms to optimize the cellular environment for recombinant protein production. Additionally, novel assembly methods such as BioBricks <Paper corpusId="10075821" paperTitle="(Shetty et al., 2008)" isShortName></Paper>, Gibson assembly, and Golden Gate <Paper corpusId="11013801" paperTitle="(Engler et al., 2008)" isShortName></Paper> have revolutionized the construction of complex genetic circuits, offering different levels of complexity for final genetic systems <Paper corpusId="276256332" paperTitle="(Matera et al., 2025)" isShortName></Paper>.

Integration of synthetic genetic circuits has provided new approaches to protein expression regulation. For example, self-regulatory protein production systems that couple recombinant protein expression with stress-induced negative feedback mechanisms have been developed to optimize production while minimizing cellular stress <Paper corpusId="255984074" paperTitle="(Dragosits et al._1, 2012)" isShortName></Paper>. Such innovations allow for intelligent expression systems that respond dynamically to cellular conditions.

Both plasmid-based expression and genome integration approaches have been developed for heterologous expression in bacterial hosts <Paper corpusId="276256332" paperTitle="(Matera et al., 2025)" isShortName></Paper> <Paper corpusId="238477289" paperTitle="(Bayer et al., 2021)" isShortName></Paper>. While plasmid-based systems offer flexibility, chromosomal integration provides stability and eliminates the need for antibiotic selection pressure. Novel methodologies like Standardized Genome Architecture (SEGA) have simplified genome engineering to make it nearly as accessible as plasmid manipulation <Paper corpusId="238477289" paperTitle="(Bayer et al., 2021)" isShortName></Paper>.

Advances in automated gene synthesis and molecular biology pipelines have further facilitated heterologous expression, enabling rapid engineering and production of recombinant proteins <Paper corpusId="268946815" paperTitle="(Plouviez et al., 2024)" isShortName></Paper>. These developments have broadened the horizon of heterologous protein production across multiple expression platforms <Paper corpusId="233868127" paperTitle="(Tungekar et al., 2021)" isShortName></Paper>, enabling precisely controlled protein synthesis rates through constructive promoters and ribosome-binding sites <Paper corpusId="267175973" paperTitle="(Abdulsalam et al., 2024)" isShortName></Paper>.

The modular and hierarchical framework of synthetic biology—organizing biological components into parts, devices, systems, and chassis—provides a powerful approach for studying and controlling cellular functions related to protein expression <Paper corpusId="5632303" paperTitle="(Alper et al., 2011)" isShortName></Paper>. Recent standardization efforts, such as Golden Standard Modular Cloning, are addressing compatibility issues between different cloning systems, promoting interoperability and efficient reusability of part libraries <Paper corpusId="262046315" paperTitle="(Blazquez et al., 2023)" isShortName></Paper>. These standardization efforts facilitate community-driven development and enhance the predictability of experimental outcomes across different laboratories.

paper.title: A synthetic biology approach to self-regulatory recombinant protein production in Escherichia coli

snippets: Recombinant protein production is a process of great industrial interest, with products that range from pharmaceuticals to biofuels. Since high level production of recombinant protein imposes significant stress in the host organism, several methods have been developed over the years to optimize protein production. So far, these trial-and-error techniques have proved laborious and sensitive to process parameters, while there has been no attempt to address the problem by applying Synthetic Biology principles and methods, such as integration of standardized parts in novel synthetic circuits.

paper.title: A synthetic biology approach to self-regulatory recombinant protein production in Escherichia coli

snippets: Recombinant protein production is a process of great industrial interest, with products that range from pharmaceuticals to biofuels. Since high level production of recombinant protein imposes significant stress in the host organism, several methods have been developed over the years to optimize protein production. So far, these trial-and-error techniques have proved laborious and sensitive to process parameters, while there has been no attempt to address the problem by applying Synthetic Biology principles and methods, such as integration of standardized parts in novel synthetic circuits. We present a novel self-regulatory protein production system that couples the control of recombinant protein production with a stress-induced, negative feedback mechanism.

paper.title: Engineering Biology to Construct Microbial Chassis for the Production of Difficult-to-Express Proteins

snippets: Functional protein expression has met a dramatic shift paralleled with the advances in systems and synthetic biology; that is, data-driven understanding in systems biology has provisioned a knowledge-based framework on which to rationally design, build, and test biological entities in an increasingly sophisticated manner (Choe et al., 2016). For instance, the following have altogether enabled characterization of the bacterial host and recombinant proteins at the systems level: a large influx of high-throughput information on DNA, RNA, proteins, and metabolites that enabled visualization of the global landscape of transcriptional and translational processes (Cho et al., 2009)(Nakahigashi et al., 2009); availability of robust computational tools and in silico models streamlining detailed analysis and prediction of the cellular networks; and rapid advances in DNA synthesis, assembly techniques that facilitated the process to build and test the designed biological systems (Gibson et al., 2009)[28].

paper.title: Systematic phenome analysis of Escherichia coli multiple-knockout mutants reveals hidden reactions in central carbon metabolism

snippets: Central carbon metabolism is a basic and exhaustively analyzed pathway. However, the intrinsic robustness of the pathway might still conceal uncharacterized reactions. To test this hypothesis, we constructed systematic multiple‐knockout mutants involved in central carbon catabolism in Escherichia coli and tested their growth under 12 different nutrient conditions. Differences between in silico predictions and experimental growth indicated that unreported reactions existed within this extensively analyzed metabolic network. These putative reactions were then confirmed by metabolome analysis and in vitro enzymatic assays. Novel reactions regarding the breakdown of sedoheptulose‐7‐phosphate to erythrose‐4‐phosphate and dihydroxyacetone phosphate were observed in transaldolase‐deficient mutants, without any noticeable changes in gene expression. These reactions, triggered by an accumulation of sedoheptulose‐7‐phosphate, were catalyzed by the universally conserved glycolytic enzymes ATP‐dependent phosphofructokinase and aldolase. The emergence of an alternative pathway not requiring any changes in gene expression, but rather relying on the accumulation of an intermediate metabolite may be a novel mechanism mediating the robustness of these metabolic networks.

snippets: In recent years, biosynthesis techniques have attracted increased attention. As synthetic biology applications have grown in complexity, so too has the sophistication of available genetic and biochemical tools. For example, researchers started to produce antibiotic using microbial fermentation in the mid-20th century (Baneyx, 1999). Currently, a dramatic change in the scope and complexity manufacturing processes within the space of synthetic biology has occurred. Thanks to development of genetic engineering, accomplishments have progressed from simple reconstitution of biosynthetic pathways in heterologous hosts to ambitious refactoring efforts (Yamanaka et al., 2014)(Shao et al., 2013)(Temme et al., 2012) that can produce high titers of medicinally relevant compounds (strictosamide, taxa-diene, etc. ) (Brown et al., 2015)(Soliman et al., 2015) or amino acids (L-valine, L-threonine, etc. ) (Park et al., 2007)(Lee et al., 2007). Up to now, synthetic biologists have employed many tools to modify and reform bacterial strains to produce desired compounds. These tools include well-characterized sets of expression vectors (Lee et al., 2011), promoters for dynamic pathway control (Dahl et al., 2013)(Zhang et al., 2012), tunable protein degradation (Cameron et al., 2014), and advanced methods for genome editing (Wang et al., 2009)(Hsu et al., 2014).

paper.title: BglBrick vectors and datasheets: A synthetic biology platform for gene expression

snippets: BackgroundAs engineered biological systems become more complex, it is increasingly common to express multiple operons from different plasmids and inducible expression systems within a single host cell. Optimizing such systems often requires screening combinations of origins of replication, expression systems, and antibiotic markers. This procedure is hampered by a lack of quantitative data on how these components behave when more than one origin of replication or expression system are used simultaneously. Additionally, this process can be time consuming as it often requires the creation of new vectors or cloning into existing but disparate vectors.ResultsHere, we report the development and characterization of a library of expression vectors compatible with the BglBrick standard (BBF RFC 21). We have designed and constructed 96 BglBrick-compatible plasmids with a combination of replication origins, antibiotic resistance genes, and inducible promoters. These plasmids were characterized over a range of inducer concentrations, in the presence of non-cognate inducer molecules, and with several growth media, and their characteristics were documented in a standard format datasheet. A three plasmid system was used to investigate the impact of multiple origins of replication on plasmid copy number.ConclusionsThe standardized collection of vectors presented here allows the user to rapidly construct and test the expression of genes with various combinations of promoter strength, inducible expression system, copy number, and antibiotic resistance. The quantitative datasheets created for these vectors will increase the predictability of gene expression, especially when multiple plasmids and inducers are utilized.

Precise control of protein synthesis rates can be achieved with constructive promoters, ribosome-binding sites, etc. Synthetic circuits have also been speeded up with gene synthesis and CRISPR/Cas9-based genome editing through high throughput gene synthesis. paper.title: Engineering BioBrick vectors from BioBrick parts

snippets: BackgroundThe underlying goal of synthetic biology is to make the process of engineering biological systems easier. Recent work has focused on defining and developing standard biological parts. The technical standard that has gained the most traction in the synthetic biology community is the BioBrick standard for physical composition of genetic parts. Parts that conform to the BioBrick assembly standard are BioBrick standard biological parts. To date, over 2,000 BioBrick parts have been contributed to, and are available from, the Registry of Standard Biological Parts.ResultsHere we extended the same advantages of BioBrick standard biological parts to the plasmid-based vectors that are used to provide and propagate BioBrick parts. We developed a process for engineering BioBrick vectors from BioBrick parts. We designed a new set of BioBrick parts that encode many useful vector functions. We combined the new parts to make a BioBrick base vector that facilitates BioBrick vector construction. We demonstrated the utility of the process by constructing seven new BioBrick vectors. We also successfully used the resulting vectors to assemble and propagate other BioBrick standard biological parts.ConclusionWe extended the principles of part reuse and standardization to BioBrick vectors. As a result, myriad new BioBrick vectors can be readily produced from all existing and newly designed BioBrick parts. We invite the synthetic biology community to (1) use the process to make and share new BioBrick vectors; (2) expand the current collection of BioBrick vector parts; and (3) characterize and improve the available collection of BioBrick vector parts.

paper.title: A One Pot, One Step, Precision Cloning Method with High Throughput Capability

snippets: Current cloning technologies based on site-specific recombination are efficient, simple to use, and flexible, but have the drawback of leaving recombination site sequences in the final construct, adding an extra 8 to 13 amino acids to the expressed protein. We have devised a simple and rapid subcloning strategy to transfer any DNA fragment of interest from an entry clone into an expression vector, without this shortcoming. The strategy is based on the use of type IIs restriction enzymes, which cut outside of their recognition sequence. With proper design of the cleavage sites, two fragments cut by type IIs restriction enzymes can be ligated into a product lacking the original restriction site. Based on this property, a cloning strategy called ‘Golden Gate’ cloning was devised that allows to obtain in one tube and one step close to one hundred percent correct recombinant plasmids after just a 5 minute restriction-ligation. This method is therefore as efficient as currently used recombination-based cloning technologies but yields recombinant plasmids that do not contain unwanted sequences in the final construct, thus providing precision for this fundamental process of genetic manipulation.

snippets: Molecular and synthetic biology tools enable the design of new-to-nature biological systems, including genetically engineered microorganisms, recombinant proteins, and novel metabolic pathways. These tools simplify the development of more efficient, manageable, and tailored solutions for specific applications, biocatalysts, or biosensors that are devoid of undesirable characteristics. The key aspect of preparing these biological systems is the availability of appropriate strategies for designing novel genetic circuits. However, there remains a pressing need to explore independent and controllable systems for the co-expression of multiple genes

paper.title: A standardized genome architecture for bacterial synthetic biology (SEGA)

snippets: Chromosomal recombinant gene expression offers a number of advantages over plasmid-based synthetic biology. However, the methods applied for bacterial genome engineering are still challenging and far from being standardized. Here, in an attempt to realize the simplest recombinant genome technology imaginable and facilitate the transition from recombinant plasmids to genomes, we create a simplistic methodology and a comprehensive strain collection called the Standardized Genome Architecture (SEGA). In its simplest form, SEGA enables genome engineering by combining only two reagents: a DNA fragment that can be ordered from a commercial vendor and a stock solution of bacterial cells followed by incubation on agar plates. Recombinant genomes are identified by visual inspection using green-white colony screening akin to classical blue-white screening for recombinant plasmids. The modular nature of SEGA allows precise multi-level control of transcriptional, translational, and post-translational regulation. The SEGA architecture simultaneously supports increased standardization of genetic designs and a broad application range by utilizing well-characterized parts optimized for robust performance in the context of the bacterial genome. Ultimately, its adaption and expansion by the scientific community should improve predictability and comparability of experimental outcomes across different laboratories. Genome engineering is challenging compared to plasmid DNA manipulation. Here the authors create a simple methodology called SEGA that enables genome engineering by combining DNA and bacterial cells followed by identification of recombinant clones by a change in colour when grown on agar plates.

paper.title: Golden Standard: a complete standard, portable, and interoperative MoClo tool for model and non-model proteobacteria

snippets: Abstract Modular cloning has become a benchmark technology in synthetic biology. However, a notable disparity exists between its remarkable development and the need for standardization to facilitate seamless interoperability among systems. The field is thus impeded by an overwhelming proliferation of organism-specific systems that frequently lack compatibility. To overcome these issues, we present Golden Standard (GS), a Type IIS assembly method underpinned by the Standard European Vector Architecture. GS unlocks modular cloning applications for most bacteria, and delivers combinatorial multi-part assembly to create genetic circuits of up to twenty transcription units (TUs). Reliance on MoClo syntax renders GS fully compatible with many existing tools and it sets the path towards efficient reusability of available part libraries and assembled TUs. GS was validated in terms of DNA assembly, portability, interoperability and phenotype engineering in α-, β-, γ- and δ-proteobacteria. Furthermore, we provide a computational pipeline for parts characterization that was used to assess the performance of GS parts. To promote community-driven development of GS, we provide a dedicated web-portal including a repository of parts, vectors, and Wizard and Setup tools that guide users in designing constructs. Overall, GS establishes an open, standardized framework propelling the progress of synthetic biology as a whole.

sections.title: Host Organisms and Expression Systems
sections.tldr: Different host organisms offer unique advantages for recombinant protein expression, with E. coli remaining the most widely used prokaryotic system while yeasts, Streptomyces, and engineered probiotics provide alternative platforms with specialized capabilities. Recent synthetic biology advances have expanded the toolkit for optimizing these expression systems through genome engineering, codon optimization, and pathway refactoring. (11 sources)
sections.text:
The selection of appropriate host organisms is a critical consideration in recombinant protein expression, with synthetic biology approaches now enabling unprecedented optimization of these expression platforms. Among many available systems, Escherichia coli remains one of the most attractive and widely used prokaryotic hosts due to its rapid growth rate, ability to utilize inexpensive substrates, well-characterized genetics, and the availability of numerous cloning vectors and mutant strains <Paper corpusId="87270106" paperTitle="(Lin et al., 2014)" isShortName></Paper>. E. coli has established itself as the standard platform for expression and optimization of heterologous biosynthetic pathways, particularly for industrial production through batch and fed-batch operations <Paper corpusId="87270106" paperTitle="(Lin et al., 2014)" isShortName></Paper>.

Yeasts represent another important class of expression hosts that have been extensively engineered for enhanced protein production. Recent synthetic biology approaches have focused on constructing yeast cell factories with improved capacities for protein folding, secretion, and post-translational modifications <Paper corpusId="211015523" paperTitle="(Thak et al., 2020)" isShortName></Paper>. These advancements include the development of codon-optimized synthetic genes, combinatory synthetic signal peptides, and copy number-controllable integration systems. Furthermore, engineering of the endoplasmic reticulum, protein trafficking pathways, synthetic glycosylation, and cell-wall components has significantly improved both the quality and yield of secretory recombinant proteins in yeast systems <Paper corpusId="211015523" paperTitle="(Thak et al., 2020)" isShortName></Paper>.

Streptomyces species have emerged as promising alternative hosts for heterologous protein production due to their natural capability to express various secondary metabolite biosynthetic gene clusters and secretory enzymes <Paper corpusId="245336991" paperTitle="(Hwang et al., 2021)" isShortName></Paper>. Despite their advantages, challenges such as low yield, difficulty in genetic manipulation, and complex cellular features have historically limited their widespread adoption <Paper corpusId="245336991" paperTitle="(Hwang et al., 2021)" isShortName></Paper>. However, new genetic tools are addressing these limitations, including standardized orthogonal integration vectors and improved methods to monitor protein production <Paper corpusId="87270106" paperTitle="(Lin et al., 2014)" isShortName></Paper> <Paper corpusId="6443731" paperTitle="(Phelan et al., 2017)" isShortName></Paper>.

The reach of synthetic biology-mediated genome engineering has expanded significantly across a wide range of organisms, now including bacteria, viruses, yeast, Drosophila, zebrafish, and mammalian cells <Paper corpusId="204026804" paperTitle="(Khambhati et al., 2019)" isShortName></Paper>. This expansion has been largely driven by the development of CRISPR/Cas9 technologies, which have revolutionized genome editing capabilities across diverse organisms <Paper corpusId="204026804" paperTitle="(Khambhati et al., 2019)" isShortName></Paper> <Paper corpusId="665503" paperTitle="(DiCarlo et al., 2013)" isShortName></Paper> <Paper corpusId="18127337" paperTitle="(Hisano et al., 2015)" isShortName></Paper>. For example, in yeast, CRISPR-Cas9 has been shown to increase homologous recombination rates dramatically, with near 100% donor DNA recombination frequency when co-transforming a gRNA plasmid and donor DNA in cells constitutively expressing Cas9 <Paper corpusId="665503" paperTitle="(DiCarlo et al., 2013)" isShortName></Paper>.

The implementation of the "Design-Build-Test-Learn" (DBTL) biological engineering cycle has enabled the development of standardized and universal biological component modules that can be designed, constructed, integrated, tested, and optimized in simple chassis cells <Paper corpusId="235998275" paperTitle="(Xiang et al., 2021)" isShortName></Paper> <Paper corpusId="222837975" paperTitle="(Meng et al., 2020)" isShortName></Paper>. This approach has been particularly valuable for constructing efficient, quantitative, and controllable platform-based living systems for various applications, including environmental remediation <Paper corpusId="235998275" paperTitle="(Xiang et al., 2021)" isShortName></Paper>.

Recent innovations in pathway refactoring have transformed the field by decoupling pathway expression from complex native regulations. This synthetic biology approach involves rebuilding entire biosynthetic pathways using plug-and-play scaffolds and heterologous promoters that function effectively in target heterologous hosts <Paper corpusId="87270106" paperTitle="(Lin et al., 2014)" isShortName></Paper> <Paper corpusId="3164113" paperTitle="(Shao et al., 2013)" isShortName></Paper>. Such strategies have successfully activated silent pathways in Streptomyces and other organisms, bypassing traditional laborious processes to elicit pathway expression <Paper corpusId="3164113" paperTitle="(Shao et al., 2013)" isShortName></Paper>.

The elucidation of genetic and biological characteristics of probiotics has also led to the development of engineered bacteria as expression systems <Paper corpusId="274838144" paperTitle="(Luo et al., 2024)" isShortName></Paper>. These advances in genetic editing technologies have enabled precise modification of probiotics, expanding the range of potential expression hosts for specialized applications <Paper corpusId="274838144" paperTitle="(Luo et al., 2024)" isShortName></Paper>.

As synthetic biology continues to evolve, the integration of diverse genetic tools and cellular engineering strategies across multiple host organisms is creating increasingly sophisticated expression systems with enhanced capabilities for recombinant protein production. This diversification of expression platforms provides researchers with a broader range of options to address specific production challenges and optimize protein yield, quality, and functionality for various applications.

snippets: In this mini-review, we discuss recent developments in synthetic biology approaches to constructing yeast cell factories endowed with enhanced capacities of protein folding and secretion as well as designed targeted post-translational modification process functions. However, there are several issues that limit their use, including low yield, difficulty in genetic manipulation, and their complex cellular features.

paper.title: Development of Next Generation Synthetic Biology Tools for Use in Streptomyces venezuelae.

snippets: Streptomyces have a rich history as producers of important natural products and this genus of bacteria has recently garnered attention for its potential applications in the broader context of synthetic biology. However, the dearth of genetic tools available to control and monitor protein production precludes rapid and predictable metabolic engineering that is possible in hosts such as Escherichia coli or Saccharomyces cerevisiae. In an effort to improve genetic tools for Streptomyces venezuelae, we developed a suite of standardized, orthogonal integration vectors and an improved method to monitor protein production in this host. These tools were applied to characterize heterologous promoters and various attB chromosomal integration sites. A final study leveraged the characterized toolset to demonstrate its use in producing the biofuel precursor bisabolene using a chromosomally integrated expression system. These tools advance S. venezuelae to be a practical host for future metabolic engineering efforts.

paper.title: Genome engineering in Saccharomyces cerevisiae using CRISPR-Cas systems

snippets: Clustered Regularly Interspaced Short Palindromic Repeats (CRISPR) and CRISPR-associated (Cas) systems in bacteria and archaea use RNA-guided nuclease activity to provide adaptive immunity against invading foreign nucleic acids. Here, we report the use of type II bacterial CRISPR-Cas system in Saccharomyces cerevisiae for genome engineering. The CRISPR-Cas components, Cas9 gene and a designer genome targeting CRISPR guide RNA (gRNA), show robust and specific RNA-guided endonuclease activity at targeted endogenous genomic loci in yeast. Using constitutive Cas9 expression and a transient gRNA cassette, we show that targeted double-strand breaks can increase homologous recombination rates of single- and double-stranded oligonucleotide donors by 5-fold and 130-fold, respectively. In addition, co-transformation of a gRNA plasmid and a donor DNA in cells constitutively expressing Cas9 resulted in near 100% donor DNA recombination frequency. Our approach provides foundations for a simple and powerful genome engineering tool for site-specific mutagenesis and allelic replacement in yeast.

paper.title: Precise in-frame integration of exogenous DNA mediated by CRISPR/Cas9 system in zebrafish

snippets: The CRISPR/Cas9 system provides a powerful tool for genome editing in various model organisms, including zebrafish. The establishment of targeted gene-disrupted zebrafish (knockouts) is readily achieved by CRISPR/Cas9-mediated genome modification. Recently, exogenous DNA integration into the zebrafish genome via homology-independent DNA repair was reported, but this integration contained various mutations at the junctions of genomic and integrated DNA. Thus, precise genome modification into targeted genomic loci remains to be achieved. Here, we describe efficient, precise CRISPR/Cas9-mediated integration using a donor vector harbouring short homologous sequences (10–40 bp) flanking the genomic target locus. We succeeded in integrating with high efficiency an exogenous mCherry or eGFP gene into targeted genes (tyrosinase and krtt1c19e) in frame. We found the precise in-frame integration of exogenous DNA without backbone vector sequences when Cas9 cleavage sites were introduced at both sides of the left homology arm, the eGFP sequence and the right homology arm. Furthermore, we confirmed that this precise genome modification was heritable. This simple method enables precise targeted gene knock-in in zebrafish.

paper.title: Biodegradation of aromatic pollutants meets synthetic biology

snippets: In recent years, with the rapid development of synthetic biology, microbial remediation has been drawing increased attention and shown the great potential in degrading pollutants compared to traditional physical and chemical methods. In the last decade, by the means of "top-down" and "bottom-up" engineering approaches, synthetic biology has been proven to be a very powerful tool in utilization and modification of existing genetic materials to redesign organisms with desired abilities. Taking "Design-Build-Test-Learn (DBTL)" biological engineering cycle, the standardized and universal biological component modules could be designed, constructed, integrated, tested and optimized in simple chassis cells to achieve efficient operation of a quantitative and controllable platform-based new living system (Meng et al., 2020).

paper.title: Refactoring the silent spectinabilin gene cluster using a plug-and-play scaffold.

snippets: Natural products (secondary metabolites) are a rich source of compounds with important biological activities. Eliciting pathway expression is always challenging but extremely important in natural product discovery because an individual pathway is tightly controlled through a unique regulation mechanism and hence often remains silent under the routine culturing conditions. To overcome the drawbacks of the traditional approaches that lack general applicability, we developed a simple synthetic biology approach that decouples pathway expression from complex native regulations. Briefly, the entire silent biosynthetic pathway is refactored using a plug-and-play scaffold and a set of heterologous promoters that are functional in a heterologous host under the target culturing condition. Using this strategy, we successfully awakened the silent spectinabilin pathway from Streptomyces orinoci. This strategy bypasses the traditional laborious processes to elicit pathway expression and represents a new platform for discovering novel natural products.

sections.title: Cell-Free Protein Synthesis and Alternative Expression Approaches
sections.tldr: Cell-free protein synthesis (CFPS) systems have emerged as powerful alternatives to traditional in vivo expression, offering rapid production without cell viability constraints. These systems complement innovative approaches like split-intein technology and genetically encoded click chemistry that enable the assembly of complex protein structures otherwise difficult to express in cellular systems. (2 sources)
sections.text:
Cell-free protein synthesis (CFPS) technologies represent a significant advancement in recombinant protein production, providing researchers with platforms for rapid and inexpensive protein expression outside the constraints of living cells <Paper corpusId="3157570" paperTitle="(Perez et al., 2016)" isShortName></Paper>. Unlike traditional in vivo systems, CFPS eliminates concerns related to cell viability, toxicity, and inclusion body formation, enabling the synthesis of proteins that might be challenging to produce in cellular environments <Model name="Anthropic" version="claude-3-7-sonnet-20250219">. These systems have become increasingly valuable tools in synthetic biology applications, offering a streamlined approach for prototyping genetic circuits and producing difficult-to-express proteins <Paper corpusId="3157570" paperTitle="(Perez et al., 2016)" isShortName></Paper>.

Beyond CFPS, innovative protein assembly strategies have expanded the toolkit for creating complex recombinant proteins. Split-intein technology has demonstrated particular utility for assembling exceptionally large proteins that would be difficult to express as single polypeptides in conventional systems. For example, researchers have successfully employed this approach to create massive 556 kDa spider silk products by assembling two separately expressed large spider silk spidroins <Paper corpusId="233682547" paperTitle="(Malyutin et al., 2021)" isShortName></Paper>. Similarly, scientists studying underwater adhesion have utilized split-intein systems to create high-molecular oligomers of recombinant mussel foot proteins with enhanced adhesion properties <Paper corpusId="233682547" paperTitle="(Malyutin et al., 2021)" isShortName></Paper>.

Alternative approaches include genetically encoded click chemistry labels that enable spontaneous formation of covalent bonds under physiological conditions between genetically encoded domains, as well as sorting-based assembly techniques <Paper corpusId="233682547" paperTitle="(Malyutin et al., 2021)" isShortName></Paper>. These methods allow researchers to express smaller heterogeneous protein subunits separately and then combine them into larger biomaterials with complex properties. Such modular expression strategies exemplify how synthetic biology and protein engineering approaches are creating new possibilities for producing functional ribosomal biomaterials that would be challenging or impossible to create using conventional single-step expression systems <Paper corpusId="233682547" paperTitle="(Malyutin et al., 2021)" isShortName></Paper>.

The development of these alternative expression approaches represents an important complement to traditional cellular systems, offering researchers greater flexibility in producing proteins with diverse structural and functional characteristics. As these technologies continue to mature, they are likely to play an increasingly important role in both fundamental research and applied biotechnology applications requiring complex recombinant proteins <Model name="Anthropic" version="claude-3-7-sonnet-20250219">.

sections.title: Applications and Industrial Impact of Enhanced Protein Expression Systems
sections.tldr: Enhanced protein expression systems have revolutionized multiple industries including biopharmaceuticals, sustainable chemistry, and food production. These technological advances have enabled the development of cell factories for producing medicines, chemicals, and novel biological materials while providing more affordable and scalable production methods. (7 sources)
sections.text:
The advancement of recombinant protein expression systems has profoundly impacted numerous industrial sectors, transforming both established industries and creating opportunities in emerging fields. Synthetic biology approaches have significantly facilitated metabolic engineering, enabling the directed modification of metabolic pathways for microbial synthesis of various products <Paper corpusId="104386515" paperTitle="(Lee et al., 2018)" isShortName></Paper> <Paper corpusId="45561844" paperTitle="(Stephanopoulos, 2012)" isShortName></Paper>. This engineering of cellular factories has become central to the biological manufacturing of chemical and pharmaceutical products, establishing a paradigm where cells function as production units for valuable compounds <Paper corpusId="45561844" paperTitle="(Stephanopoulos, 2012)" isShortName></Paper>.

The industrial applications of enhanced protein expression systems span multiple sectors. In the pharmaceutical industry, engineered cells now serve as biofactories for producing medicines including insulin and vaccines, offering more affordable and scalable production methods compared to traditional approaches <Paper corpusId="266397647" paperTitle="(Prajapati et al., 2023)" isShortName></Paper> <Paper corpusId="83462186" paperTitle="(Fenster et al., 2019)" isShortName></Paper>. This capability has been particularly valuable for manufacturing complex biopharmaceuticals that would be difficult or impossible to produce using chemical synthesis alone.

The chemical industry has also benefited substantially from advances in protein expression systems. The ability to create preprogrammed cellular behavior using both natural and synthetic biological components has enabled numerous biotechnological advancements in the biosynthesis of chemical products <Paper corpusId="266397647" paperTitle="(Prajapati et al., 2023)" isShortName></Paper>. These developments have been facilitated by next-generation sequencing techniques that allow for rapid analysis of extensive libraries of genetic components, accelerating research related to chemical product biosynthesis <Paper corpusId="266397647" paperTitle="(Prajapati et al., 2023)" isShortName></Paper>.

In the field of natural product discovery and development, advances in synthetic biology and bioinformatics have introduced new methods for producing ribosomally synthesized and post-translationally modified peptides (RiPPs). These methods include strategies for heterologous expression, genetic refactoring, and exploiting enzyme substrate tolerance to create novel analogs with improved or entirely new functions <Paper corpusId="269174525" paperTitle="(Han et al., 2024)" isShortName></Paper>. Such approaches have opened new avenues for developing bioactive compounds with potential applications in medicine and agriculture.

The focus of protein engineering has notably shifted from technology innovation to application exploration, reflecting its growing industrial importance <Paper corpusId="67790548" paperTitle="(Li, 2012)" isShortName></Paper>. While continuing to play a significant role in established industries such as detergent enzyme production, protein engineering now provides solutions in emerging sectors including biopharmaceuticals through evolved biologics and renewable energy through engineered enzymes for biofuel production <Paper corpusId="67790548" paperTitle="(Li, 2012)" isShortName></Paper>.

The microbiome engineering field has also been transformed by synthetic biology approaches to protein expression. By incorporating synthetic genetic components into designed microorganisms, researchers have expanded their ability to perceive, record, and respond to their immediate environment <Paper corpusId="266397647" paperTitle="(Prajapati et al., 2023)" isShortName></Paper> <Paper corpusId="3843287" paperTitle="(Bober et al., 2018)" isShortName></Paper>. This capability has enabled the development of probiotics and other microbiome-based therapeutics that can be engineered to deliver specific health benefits through controlled protein expression.

As these technologies continue to mature, the industrial impact of enhanced protein expression systems is likely to grow even further, enabling more sustainable production methods across multiple sectors and facilitating the development of novel products with improved properties and functionalities.

paper.title: Advancement of Metabolic Engineering Assisted by Synthetic Biology

snippets: Synthetic biology has provided advanced toolsets and novel systems, which significantly facilitate the development of metabolic engineering (Keasling, 2012)(Stephanopoulos, 2012).

paper.title: Synthetic biology and metabolic engineering.

snippets: Metabolic engineering emerged 20 years ago as the discipline occupied with the directed modification of metabolic pathways for the microbial synthesis of various products. As such, it deals with the engineering (design, construction, and optimization) of native as well as non-natural routes of product synthesis, aided in this task by the availability of synthetic DNA, the core enabling technology of synthetic biology. The two fields, however, only partially overlap in their interest in pathway engineering. While fabrication of biobricks, synthetic cells, genetic circuits, and nonlinear cell dynamics, along with pathway engineering, have occupied researchers in the field of synthetic biology, the sum total of these areas does not constitute a coherent definition of synthetic biology with a distinct intellectual foundation and well-defined areas of application. This paper reviews the origins of the two fields and advances two distinct paradigms for each of them: that of unit operations for metabolic engineering and electronic circuits for synthetic biology. In this context, metabolic engineering is about engineering cell factories for the biological manufacturing of chemical and pharmaceutical products, whereas the main focus of synthetic biology is fundamental biological research facilitated by the use of synthetic DNA and genetic circuits.

paper.title: Postbiotic production: harnessing the power of microbial metabolites for health applications

snippets: In the rapidly expanding field of synthetic biology, preprogrammed cellular behavior is attempted to be created and realized utilizing both natural and synthetic biological components. Numerous biotechnological advancements, ranging from sophisticated medicines to the biosynthesis of chemical products, have been made because of this form of forward engineering (Ullah et al., 2016). The development and fast analysis of extensive libraries of genetic components by nextgeneration sequencing techniques facilitated the advancement in the research related to the biosynthesis of chemical products. Synthetic cell-to-cell communication, intricate and expansive genomic circuits, and CRISPR-based regulation are noteworthy advancements (Markowiak-Kopeć et al., 2020). Synthetic biology offers a way to research structure-function interactions among bacteria and create new biotic treatments in the field of microbiota engineering. The ability of the designed microorganism to perceive, record, and react to its immediate environment is expanded by incorporating synthetic genetic components (Bober et al., 2018). Synthetic biology is essential to post-biotic production because it allows for the efficient and sustainable manufacture of useful substances using living organisms or biological components. Furthermore, synthetic biology has made it possible to build biofactories where created cells manufacture medicines like insulin and vaccines, providing more affordable and scalable production techniques (Fenster et al., 2019).

paper.title: The Production and Delivery of Probiotics: A Review of a Practical Approach

snippets: To successfully deliver probiotic benefits to the consumer, several criteria must be met. Here, we discuss the often-forgotten challenges in manufacturing the strains and incorporating them in consumer products that provide the required dose at the end of shelf life. For manufacturing, an intricate production process is required that ensures both high yield and stability and must also be able to meet requirements such as the absence of specific allergens, which precludes some obvious culture media ingredients. Reproducibility is important to ensure constant high performance and quality. To ensure this, quality control throughout the whole production process, from raw materials to the final product, is essential, as is the documentation of this quality control. Consumer product formulation requires extensive skill and experience. Traditionally, probiotic lactic acid bacteria and bifidobacteria have been incorporated in fermented dairy products, with limited shelf life and refrigerated storage. Currently, probiotics may be incorporated in dietary supplements and other "dry" food matrices which are expected to have up to 24 months of stability at ambient temperature and humidity. With the right choice of production process, product formulation, and strains, high-quality probiotics can be successfully included in a wide variety of delivery formats to suit consumer requirements.

paper.title: Advancements in the Application of Ribosomally Synthesized and Post-Translationally Modified Peptides (RiPPs)

snippets: Advances in synthetic biology and bioinformatics have significantly advanced the field, introducing new methods for RiPP production and engineering. These methods encompass strategies for heterologous expression, genetic refactoring, and exploiting the substrate tolerance of tailoring enzymes to create novel RiPP analogs with improved or entirely new functions.

paper.title: Beyond Protein Engineering: its Applications in Synthetic Biology

While protein engineering continues to play an important role in established industries like detergent enzymes, it also promises to provide new solutions in emerging industries such as biopharmaceuticals [evolved biologics] and renewable energy [engineered enzymes for biofuel production].

paper.title: Synthetic Biology Approaches to Engineer Probiotics and Members of the Human Microbiota for Biomedical Applications.

snippets: An increasing number of studies have strongly correlated the composition of the human microbiota with many human health conditions and, in several cases, have shown that manipulating the microbiota directly affects health. These insights have generated significant interest in engineering indigenous microbiota community members and nonresident probiotic bacteria as biotic diagnostics and therapeutics that can probe and improve human health. In this review, we discuss recent advances in synthetic biology to engineer commensal and probiotic lactic acid bacteria, bifidobacteria, and Bacteroides for these purposes, and we provide our perspective on the future potential of these technologies.
